Detailed Description

Small utility functions and macros to ease programming of Octeon.

#define CVMX_CONTAINTER_OF ( _p,
_t,
_m   ) 
Value:
({      \
    const typeof(((_t *)0)->_m) *__mp = (_p);   \
    (_t *)((char *)__mp - offsetof(_t, _m));})

Convert a pointer to a field to a pointer to the enclosing structure.

Parameters:
_p A pointer to a strucure field.
_t The type of the enclosing structure.
_m The field name (of _p) in the enclosing structure.
Returns:
A pointer to the enclosing object of type _t.

#define CVMX_WAIT_FOR_FIELD64 ( address,
type,
field,
op,
value,
timeout_usec   ) 
Value:
({int result;                                                       \
    do {                                                                \
        uint64_t done = cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) + (uint64_t)timeout_usec * \
                        cvmx_clock_get_rate(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) / 1000000; \
        type c;                                                         \
        while (1)                                                       \
        {                                                               \
            c.u64 = cvmx_read_csr(address);                             \
            if ((c.s.field) op (value)) {                               \
                result = 0;                                             \
                break;                                                  \
            } else if (cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) > done) {  \
                result = -1;                                            \
                break;                                                  \
            } else                                                      \
                cvmx_wait(100);                                         \
        }                                                               \
    } while (0);                                                        \
    result;})

This macro spins on a field waiting for it to reach a value.

It is common in code to need to wait for a specific field in a CSR to match a specific value. Conceptually this macro expands to:

1) read csr at "address" with a csr typedef of "type" 2) Check if ("type".s."field" "op" "value") 3) If #2 isn't true loop to #1 unless too much time has passed.

#define CVMX_WAIT_FOR_FIELD64_NODE ( node,
address,
type,
field,
op,
value,
timeout_usec   ) 
Value:
({int result;                                                           \
    do {                                                                \
        uint64_t done = cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) + (uint64_t)timeout_usec * \
        cvmx_clock_get_rate(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) / 1000000; \
        type c;                                                         \
        while (1)                                                       \
        {                                                               \
            c.u64 = cvmx_read_csr_node(node, address);                  \
            if ((c.s.field) op (value)) {                               \
            result = 0;                                             \
            break;                                                  \
        } else if (cvmx_clock_get_count(CVMX_CLOCK_CORE) > done) {  \
            result = -1;                                            \
            break;                                                  \
        } else                                                      \
            cvmx_wait(100);                                         \
        }                                                               \
    } while (0);                                                        \
    result;})

This macro spins on a field waiting for it to reach a value.

It is common in code to need to wait for a specific field in a CSR to match a specific value. Conceptually this macro expands to:

1) read csr at "address" with a csr typedef of "type" 2) Check if ("type".s."field" "op" "value") 3) If #2 isn't true loop to #1 unless too much time has passed.

static uint64_t cvmx_bit_extract ( uint64_t  input,
int  lsb,
int  width 
) [inline, static]

Extract bits out of a number.

Parameters:
input Number to extract from
lsb Starting bit, least significant (0-63)
width Width in bits (1-64)
Returns:
Extracted number
static int64_t cvmx_bit_extract_smag ( uint64_t  input,
int  lsb,
int  msb 
) [inline, static]

Extract a signed magnitude value.

Signed magnitude is a value where the MSB is treated as a sign bit, not like the mornal twos compliment.

Parameters:
input Number to extract from
lsb Starting bit, least significant (0-63)
msb which is the signed bit
Returns:
Extracted number
static uint64_t cvmx_bit_insert ( uint64_t  original,
uint64_t  input,
int  lsb,
int  width 
) [inline, static]

Insert bits into a number.

Parameters:
original Original data, before insert
input Data to insert
lsb Starting bit, least significant (0-63)
width Width in bits (1-64)
Returns:
Number with inserted bits
static uint64_t cvmx_build_bits ( uint64_t  high_bit,
uint64_t  low_bit,
uint64_t  value 
) [inline, static]

Perform mask and shift to place the supplied value into the supplied bit rage.

Example: cvmx_build_bits(39,24,value) 

 6       5       4       3       3       2       1
 3       5       7       9       1       3       5       7      0
 +-------+-------+-------+-------+-------+-------+-------+------+
 000000000000000000000000___________value000000000000000000000000
Parameters:
high_bit Highest bit value can occupy (inclusive) 0-63
low_bit Lowest bit value can occupy inclusive 0-high_bit
value Value to use
Returns:
Value masked and shifted

uint64_t  sub_did 
) [inline, static]

Builds a memory address for I/O based on the Major and Sub DID.

Parameters:
major_did 5 bit major did
sub_did 3 bit sub did
Returns:
I/O base address
